reviewText: This is my favorite comedy of all time. It wasn't much of a hit,and the first time I saw "The Duchess and the Dirtwater Fox"  was in the early 80's on HBO.I never laughed so hard in my life,especially when Goldie  and George Segal talk French to each other while ridding in the Stage  Coach.You'll be rolling on the floor when you see this part of the film.And  don't forget,"Honk Honk,"you'll know what I mean when you see the  Video. If your feeling bad tonight,go out and rent this film.
summary: If your depressed,this will snap you out of it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The Duchess and the Dirtwater Fox" is a frothy, bawdy timefiller that's just what the doctor ordered on a cold winter night.  It won't make you forget classic Western comedies like "Destry Rides Again", "Cat Ballou", or "McLintock" but it'll suffice.  What distinguishes the film is the indelible chemistry between stars George Segal and Goldie Hawn and a consistently clever and funny script.  My only real debit here is a puzzling abrupt ending but other than that there is a lot of enjoyment to be mined here.
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's finally here on DVD. When I first saw this movie in 1977, I knew that I would be seeing it again...little did I think, that I would see it much more than again...at last count, 27 times. The producers seem to have steadfastly refused to release it on DVD, keeping it in a VHS format for decades...but finally it's here in DVD, thank the Lord.It is possibly the best Goldie Hawn comedy (in close contest with Foul Play).Both Goldie Hawn & George Segal play their respective roles as the hooker & the thief-lover-gambler to perfection. They are funny, lovable & above all, entertaining.The script is outstanding...there is a sequence in a stagecoach, in pseudo-French, with a deadpan Mormon playing the straight role, which should be in the Comedy Hall of Fame (if they ever invent one). The Hawn song "you can pluck me apples...." is probably the funniest song I have ever heard. George Segal as the Dirtwater Fox is an irresistably cute rascal. The direction is excellent.Would Goldie & George consider a sequel, even 30 years later???
summary: Goldie & George - May we have another,please

reviewText: This is the story of a couple of con artists who are not truly evil but who are definitely not the types you want for neighbors.Goldie Hawn plays a San Francisco saloon singer who turns tricks to keep the income level up. She is always looking for a way to better her prospects without going through the trouble of bettering herself.George Segal plays a con-man and gambler. He doesn't like the violent stuff but will take part if forced into it. He like decorative women and Goldie Hawn has definitely caught his eye. The problem is that she sees him as just another trick and, when she learns about some of his loot, another mark to be fleeced.Segal had taken part in a bank robbery by distracting the wife of the bank manager. When the robbery gang is pursued, he is doubled crossed and left behind without any of the loot. He was expecting the double cross, however, and he really has all of the loot while the robbers get away only with horse nuggets. This leads to a precarious state of affairs. The robbers are after Segal who has to leave the country. Segal is after Hawn who is herself after the contents of his black bag. Eventually, Segal and Hawn wind up together against everyone else to secure their fair share of their ill gotten gains.The whole thing is done with a sense of humor and is amusing to watch. It is fun.
summary: A Cute and Risque Western Comedy

reviewText: Goldie Hawn is a dance hall girl with an extracurricular agenda. George Segal is a cheating gamble that seems to always get caught. Not only does he escape a hanging but walks away with the loot from the gang's bank robbery. Goldie and George both want what the other has and the laughs roll like plums.The film is set in San Fransisco and moves to Utah as Goldie disguises as a duchess to impress a wealthy Mormon, with more wives than he can count. The situation is set, as Goldie and George run from the outlaws whose money she misappropriated from George and toward Utah and the new life.A good Goldie, very laughable and a very entertaining movie.

reviewText: The 1976 western spoof entitled "The Duchess and the Dirtwater Fox", which was produced, directed and co-written by Melvin Frank (1913-1988), was not one of Goldie Hawn's better films.  Goldie plays a saloon dancer in the Old West named Amanda Quaid and meets up with a cheating gambler named Charlie 'Dirtwater Fox' Malloy (George Segal).  After Charlie is forced to help a band of desperados rob a nearby bank, then manage to steal the booty for himself, he is seduced by Amanda, who drugs him to sleep and takes his bag of money, but doesn't realize how much money the bag actually contains hidden within.  She uses the small amount of money that she found in the bag to purchase an expensive, formal black dress to impress a wealthy Mormon (Thayer David, 1927-1978) that she wants to marry.  Having done so, she and the wealthy Mormon's assistant (Conrad Janis) ride off in a stagecoach towards Salt Lake City with Charlie riding after them.  Of course, the band of desperados is after Charlie (and Amanda) because they want the stolen money back.  Rather than spoil the rest of this film's plot, suffice it to say that there's some gun fighting, poker playing, a Jewish wedding (in the Old West no less), a river ride with rapids and lots of chasing on horseback across the wilderness.  The theme song for this film, composed by Charles Fox (who composed much better songs for TV shows such as "Wonder Woman" and "The Love Boat" in the same year), sounded too much like a psychedelic reworking of "Raindrops Keep Falling on My Head" (which was composed by Burt Bacharach & Hal David for the 1969 Oscar-award winning film "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid") with hints of the late 1960's song "Incense and Peppermints" by the group Strawberry Alarm Clock.Filmed in the Colorado Rocky Mountains, the outdoor cinematography was beautiful. However, the film's chaotic story, as well as its unrealistic and not particularly funny characters, detracted from the film's attempt to be an entertaining western spoof.  Surprisingly, Goldie Hawn received a Golden Globe nomination for Best Motion Picture Actress-Musical/Comedy for her work in "The Duchess and the Dirtwater Fox", but the award went instead to Barbara Streisand for "A Star is Born".  While Goldie did have a few funny scenes and funny song moments, her acting was nowhere near as good as her roles in films such as "Cactus Flower" (1969), "Butterflies are Free" (1972), "Foul Play" (1978), "Private Benjamin" (1980) or later works.  Consequently, my rating for "The Duchess and the Dirtwater Fox" is a generous 3 out of 5 stars.
summary: Mildly Funny, but Not one of Goldie Hawn's More Memorable Films

reviewText: Another of Goldie Hawn's classics! It's the story of a conman and a prostitute thrown together by the hand of fate, and their hilarious partnership. The best scene is where Goldie auditions for the job of governess to a religious family, and she must give a demonstration of her musical skills. The only song that is suitable for the circumstances, is a number she used to perform in the brothel: "Please don't touch my plums" and she does a magnificent job of impressing the pater familias and tickling the viewer's funnybone. The Duchess is a pearl in Goldie's crown.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I must've watched this 12 times as a kid when it played on Showtime and i haven't seen it since. But any movie that I am still quoting and recalling all these yrs later must hold up to the test of time and I'm betting that this is every bit as amusing as I found it to be in the late 70's.Who hasn't fallen in love with Goldie Hawn? She was great in this.George Segal says one of my all-time favorite loveable scoundrel lines, after he and Hawn and their bag of loot have fallen into the river he starts shouting, " Save the money! Save the money!" and Goldie replies, frantically, " I can't swim!" to which he replies, " Neither can the money!"  Like i said, I'm still laughing at that line today. It's a cliche to say this but THE DUCHESS & THE DIRTWATER FOX is fun for the whole family and a funny/pleasant way to spend 90 minutes. It is a very nice surprise to find it available on DVD. Bravo to all involved.

reviewText: This is a truly unique movie filmed in Central City and Georgetown, Colorado.  There are views of the Colorado Mountains all throughout this film. In the beginning of the movie George Segal is being hung for cheating at cards. The hanging scene was filmed behind the Hamill House in Georgetown Colorado in 1975.  I was seven years old and remember George Segal being there. My father was a deputy sheriff in charge of security. There were crowds watching from the parking lot behind the Hamill House. The horse comes running through the arch between the Carraige House and Hamill's office.  The production then moved to Central City where they turned it into the San Francisco Wharf and Virginia City.  There are Central City and Colorado landmarks everywhere in the film.  They covered the streets with dirt to recreate the old western charm of Central City. At the end of the movie there is a still shot of a stagecoach with Sawtooth Peak and Mt. Bierstadt up on Guanella Pass (located above Georgetown) // THis is a fun film.  Not seen by many. Highly recommended especially if you're familiar with Georgetown and Central City.
summary: Spectacular movie filmed in Central City, Colorado

reviewText: While this can be viewed as a little outrageous, and I wouldn't recommend it for the younger set...as an older adult, I saw this when it first came out and thought it was hilarious...Goldie is hysterical and George Segal is a master at timing in comedy.  I still enjoy it and have loaned it to my 'religious' friends with a 'warning' and they returned it laughing saying it was the best.  It is tongue in cheek, a little risqué, but lots of fun.

reviewText: If you love awful movies that are fun in their awfulness, this one's perfect.  The acting is bad, the story is too and the Bobby Vinton soundtrack is one for the ages.  There's nothing more ironic than songs about "Lemon Drops, Lollipops and Sunbeams" sung by someone who sounds like they're clinically depressed.  On the plus side, Goldie Hawn wears next to nothing and bends, lifts or pushes aside her costumes in almost every scene.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Born 56 years ago in  Maryland, Goldie Hawn is type-cast as the skinny, ditzy blonde of LAUGH-IN.  Of her 28 movies listed by MALTIN, she plays to type best in the farcical assassination plot of FOUL PLAY.  Actually, Ms. Hawn has an extensive acting range with serious dramatic accomplishment, as she demonstrates in her mystery suspense thriller, DECEIVED.Ms. Hawn chooses scripts with a poignant moral, consummated at the end of PROTOCOL by her passionate plea for citizens to participate in democracy, recalling Charlie Chaplin's emotional prayer for compassion at the end of THE GREAT DICTATOR.  The heartfelt messages of her movies is the probable reason for consistently satisfied  fans.George Segal is cast with Goldie as THE DUCHESS AND THE DIRTWATER FOX, a comedy only because the characters are not distressed by their predicaments, including bullet wounds in the upper body.  Comic relief does not make a fun fest; a Western played for laughs throughout is THE HALLELUJAH TRAIL starring Burt Lancaster with Lee Remick, not to mention Mel Brooks' classic BLAZING SADDLES.Through a series of contrived crises, two long hilarious scenes and five repartees lighten the serious love story of lonely, selfish, opportunistic, and desperate scoundrels, like Scarlett and Rhett.  The critical shot is the moment they realize they love each other while dancing at a Jewish wedding; don't miss their faces during those 5 seconds at the beginning of the Third Act; the whole movie hangs on it.  The story ends with their romantic consummation, but persists through three more sequences with faulty continuity and unsatisfying resolution.Ms. Hawn has no figure, but she passes no opportunity for teasing with all she has without showing skin that never gets tan.  Her thighs are delightfully photogenic; THE DUCHESS displays them in crotch shots that would shame Sharon Stone because they are gratuitous.  Goldie's fans will appreciate the striking beauty of her mature face without make-up in the scene of her staked out to die with sarcastic witticisms under the desert sun.TP
summary: The Dirt Comes Out In The Wash
